intro: Camissonia boothii subsp. intermedia, commonly known as the Sierra Valley flax, is a flowering plant native to California. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescence and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It produces small white or pale blue flowers that bloom in the spring. Its leaves are narrow, lance-shaped, and often have a silvery or grayish hue due to a dense covering of fine hairs.
